newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: S.Korean opposition blasts probe on Kim's son.
newsitem.headline: S.Korean opposition blasts probe on Kim's son.

text.p: South Korea's main opposition party attacked state prosecutors on Sunday for trying to cover up a scandal by clearing President Kim Young-sam's son of any wrongdoing over loans to the failed Hanbo Steel Co
The National Congress for New Politics insisted that a new probe was necessary into what it calls the nation's biggest financial crisis.

On Saturday prosecutors cleared Kim Hyun-chul, President Kim's second son, of any wrongdoing in connection with $5.8 billion worth of loans piled up by Hanbo Steel before it was declared insolvent on January 23.
"The probe was designed to acquit Kim Hyun-chul," said Park Sun-suck, a spokeswoman for the National Congress.
"The investigation was wrong from the start," she said. "Prosecutors were trying to cover up the suspicions surrounding him."

Kim Hyun-chul was questioned after he lodged a libel complaint last Tuesday against six opposition politicians who had alleged he pressured banks to offer loans to Hanbo Steel, flagship of South Korea's 14th-biggest conglomerate.

Kim Hyun-chul denied allegations that he had received donations in return for pressuring the banks, but speculation persisted that he had links with Hanbo, particularly after the discovery in a Hanbo Group warehouse earlier this month of more than 10,000 copies of his autobiography.
The opposition claimed the discovery was proof that Hanbo had been sponsoring Kim Hyun-chul by boosting his sales figures and his reputation.
"Rising criticism that prosecutors gave Mr Kim an opportunity to clear himself from accusations shows how people views the investigation," the leading daily Chosun Ilbo said.
"There is no one who believes the prosecutor's claim that all allegations made against Kim Hyun-chul were found to be false," it said in an editorial.
Another leading newspaper, the Dong-A Ilbo, said the unprecedented investigation of an incumbent president's son over a scandal was itself a disgrace.
"President Kim should take responsibility for letting the matter go so far," it said.
The scandal has tarnished the image of the president who launched an anti-corruption drive shortly after taking office in 1993.
On Wednesday, prosecutors indicted 10 people in the scandal, including Hanbo Group founder Chung Tae-soo and three close associates of the president, on bribery and embezzlement charges.
Prosecutors said the six National Congress politicians who alleged wrongdoing by the president's son would be summoned soon for questioning over his libel complaint.
The six include party spokesman Chung Dong-young, his deputy Sul Hoon and three other members of parliament.
But the National Congress said on Sunday the politicians would ignore the prosecution's summons because the libel investigation "lacked credibility".
President Kim, whose single five-year term expires in February 1998, is due to make a statement this week on the political situation.
